There is a thing called dysphoria, and trans people experience it even when they have transitioned. Basically, say an MtF decides to wear pants, she can experience negative feelings towards her gender identity because it reminds her of not being 'a real woman' - essentially taking on those gender stereotypes is a way to cope, in other words it is essentially over compensation by exaggerating traits we as a society have 'defined' as feminine or what a woman should have. A lot of therapy for trans people is about breaking down this dysphoria so that they can feel comfortable as a woman, recognise that they are real women without the need to wear pink every day and watch Housewives of Beverly Hills, and really come to terms with BEING a woman and not so hung up on whether or not they are 'woman enough'.
Unless our society changes and welcomes trans people rather than classifying them as fake, deceitful and not real women, they will continue to behave insecurely and rely on stereotypes which society perceives womanhood to be. Regardless, I have trans friends who do not fall into the stereotype trap, I even have a few who are trans yet identify as gender neutral - what it all relies on is their ability to be comfortable and confident in who they are and how they feel they can self express. And for that they needed a strong support unit

Therapists typically use slang because it breaks down the hierarchy between the two of you so it makes it easier to just talk. Chances are you may be reading too much into it, but you can always tell a therapist that you don't like talking about something because it makes you feel uncomfortable. You need to tell them this, they can't read your mind, but only assess you based on what you give them. If you don't want to talk about something - don't.

Our definition of pedophilia has changed a lot over the past century. A lot of people today would call Edgar Allan Poe a pedophile for marrying a 14 year old, but that was not at all unheard of at the time and relatively common. Hell, they became spinsters at 25 and were approaching old maid territory at 30. Girls married young because they were at their most fertile and were a liability to families. This was not considered to be pedophilia.
Homosexuality however was criminal in a Victorian times, and was treated as such after the first and Second World War because the population was threatened. Anyone who didn't have more than one child was also looked at with suspicion.

If you have great communication, then I really don't see the problem. My husband and I occasionally will open up the relationship, but either one of us can close it up whenever we want to and neither of us feel bad or upset if it happens. Of course, when we first did it, it was pretty scary and we were really anxious, but it wasn't too bad. I think in ways it brought us closer as a couple. Just keep in mind, that if it does go not so great for either one of you, to not take it personally - that it was a one time thing and you can both just move away from it. If you both end up liking it, well just keep up with the communication - let each other know your feelings about the other person and about being sexual with another person. There are different kinds of therapists. Counsellors are not adequately trained for managing and overcoming mental illness, they exist to help with day to day struggle, and for lending an ear, but cannot diagnose and treat. Psychiatrists prescribe medications and medicate based on your symptoms and often based on the diagnoses of a psychologist. Whilst they can diagnose mental illness, they are not the point and call for receiving therapy and for weeding out all the issues you have. A psychologist, and even a well trained mental health nurse, works to diagnose and treat mental illness - while they can perform the same tasks as a counsellor, their main job is to put you through some sort of treatment program whether it be IPT, ACT or CBT and work more closely with your illness and less with your personal problems although those will be discussed as factors that could impair.
I can say from experience, psychologists only ask about your life and opinions to build rapport. They are much more interested in the fact that you have a mental illness and want to talk about overcoming it with strategies etc, whilst also learning what barriers may be in place that prevents the therapy from working so you can try to break those down. In Australia at least, there is shift to move away from information like why you have the mental illness because studies have shown that while talking about why you have the disorder can be cathartic, it doesn't generally improve the efficacy of the therapy.
Personally, I hated counsellors. But they are the most affordable and easy to get appointments with. However, if you are dealing with a mental illness, you should be seeing a psychologist and a psychiatrist, not a counsellor. Counsellors are not adequately trained to deal with mental illness, but to recognise it so they can refer them on or to give advice.

While I wasn't an alcoholic per se, if at a party or a club, I will get absolutely shit-faced wasted. I only ever had fancy drinks so the hangovers weren't bad, just the feeling of tiredness. Still though, while my grades were good, it was hard to keep them that high whilst getting drunk on weekends and sucking dick in bathroom stalls.
Seriously, any form of cutting back is a great idea. Getting wasted even 3 times a week puts you into the criteria of an alcoholic and even alcohol abuse if it is impacting you negatively in some way. Alcohol is a terrible solution for anxiety - if you're doing it for that reason seriously see a therapist and get put on SSRIs. It saved my life.
Is your goal reasonable? Yes. It's certainly doable, but I recommend seeing a therapist to help you out with the process, because if you relapse, you always fall further than when you started.

I honestly don't think it matters either way. I believe I was born gay and that people more or less have to come to terms with their sexuality over time which experience helps them find. There is a bulk of evidence to say that we are born gay or straight or bi, but then there is a bulk of evidence counter to that. The most commonly adopted argument in psychology is that it's an interplay of nature and nurture - that our environment can help swing us one way or another, but we are born with a set point on a scale.
Say for example I was born with a gay score of 8 out of 10, but then experience and enjoying being gay and accepting a disinterest in women pushed me up to a 10. It could also go the other way where if I was more curious, and not okay with being gay, I shift down the sliding scale. This trend is commonly found in IQ - while genetics plays a large part in IQ, it can still be impacted on by experience.
Do I think people are born gay? Yes. Do I think that we live in a heteronormative society that can make gay people not notice they are gay or incidentally due to norms find women attractive? Yes.

Honestly, I don't think it really matters if it was learned behaviour or not. However, we know that we can reverse learned behaviour (a lot of fear conditioning studies and dependence/addiction studies suggest so with pharmacological, neurological and cognitive manipulations) and we know from unfortunately unethical evidence that it doesn't work for homosexuality (with the techniques we have available.
Now whether or not it's because our science is not sound enough to extinguish certain types of learned behaviour (I doubt it) is really all up in the air. And so is whether because we can't get rid of it means that people are born that way. But if an overwhelming amount of psychologists agree that sexuality is a property akin to skin colour, then that would imply that we are born to have the propensity to be gay.
Not only do I have a degree in psychology, but the quote I posted has a link to an article written by psychiatrist and psychologist Dr. Jack Drescher, MD.

You mean the DSM? Homosexuality was thought to be a mental illness because the first diagnostic manual included strongly held Freudian beliefs. It was a shit manual recommending lobotomies for all sorts of illnesses including depression. Psychology, like with any science, follows a zeitgeist - meaning if it is a commonly held belief by the public and by those willing to fund the research, it will be perpetuated. Keep in mind, it wasn't until the 1970's that the US completely abolished eugenics laws for those with an IQ below 70.
The reason sexual orientation was removed was because psychologists realised that there was no benefit in treating homosexuality, but it instead made people worse off. Also the definition of psychiatry changed - we went away from classification to diagnosing treatable and recognisable pathology. Homosexuality is not a pathology, but due to social constraints it will lead to the pathologies of depression and anxiety - those factors were treatable. In the DSM-II homosexuality was revised as little more than a footnote in something called 'sexual orientation disturbance' - however, it unfortunately legitimised conversion therapy. It wasn't until the DSM-III where it was replaced by something else which again got into hot water because it was not based on the science available at the time. A quote from a good article on the history and scientific legitimacy of the subject: it was obvious to psychiatrists more than a decade later that the inclusion first of SOD, and later EDH, was the result of earlier political compromises and that neither diagnosis met the definition of a disorder in the new nosology. [source](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC4695779/)
Some people thought it was political, HOWEVER, extensive research by Kinsey who conducted the most prolific research on human sexuality and Evelyn Hooker's research provided substantial evidence to remove homosexuality from the DSM.
You need to remember, scientific research before the 1940s was often shit, and a lot of research in the 50s and 60s were heavily paid for by anti-gay lobbyists for obvious reasons like a population disparity and anti-gay movements. For Kinsey, the amazing man, to even conduct his research in the 1940s was tremendous.

Same in Australia (on weekends it's double pay), but LOL. It still happens in privately run hospitals, quite often too. It's starting to happen in public hospitals - a fairly large one called Prince of Wales came out demanding more funding because they could not pay their staff and they had no money to buy new equipment. They relied on repairing their surgical instruments and improvising just to get by.

Standards in nursing have dropped dramatically due to funding cuts and a shortage of healthcare professionals. You have a lot of people often working unpaid overtime in the health sector. I'm at least fortunate that I am a perioperative nurse and we have more breaks than other nurses, but working 12 hour days 6 days a week does get to you. Still though, I graduated with a lot of these people and I am often amazed at who actually graduates. I remember one girl who kept asking me to convert litres into millilitres and if 2 grams of ampicillin was less than 800mg. With the health sector so desperate, you have people who shouldn't be nurses taking on managerial roles etc further perpetuating bad nursing practice. It's a fucking joke and it honestly pisses me off that some of my colleagues will make fun of the children we performed surgery on. Dark humor is fine and all, but it's getting to a point where I think a lot of nurses are believing what they are saying rather than joking.
